definition.value: Catalyzes the oxidative deamination of primary and some secondary amine such as neurotransmitters, with concomitant reduction of oxygen to hydrogen peroxide and has important functions in the metabolism of neuroactive and vasoactive amines in the central nervous system and peripheral tissues.

Catalyzes the oxidative deamination of primary and some secondary amines such as neurotransmitters, and exogenous amines including the tertiary amine, neurotoxin MPTP, with concomitant reduction of oxygen to hydrogen peroxide and participates in the metabolism of neuroactive and vasoactive amines in the central nervous system and peripheral tissues.
A protein that is a translation product of the human SLC22A6 gene.
A protein that is a translation product of the human SLC22A7 gene.
A protein that is a translation product of the SLC22A8 gene.

label.value: Solute carrier organic anion transporter family member 1B1

definition.value: Solute carrier organic anion transporter family member 1B1 is encoded by the human SLCO1B1 gene. This protein is involved in the sodium-independent uptake of endogenous compounds in the liver.

label.value: Solute carrier organic anion transporter family member 1B3

definition.value: A sodium-independent organic anion transporter that functions in the uptake of various drugs and endogenous compounds including estradiol; taurocholate; leukotriene c4; and methotrexate.

label.value: Solute carrier organic anion transporter family member 2B1

definition.value: Solute carrier organic anion transporter family member 2B1 is encoded by the human SLCO2B1 gene. This protein is involved in transport of organic anions and may function in regulation of placental uptake of sulfated steroids.
Solute carrier family 22 member 1 is encoded by the human SLC22A1 gene. This protein is involved in bidirectional cation transport.
A protein that is a translation product of the human SLC22A24 gene.
A protein that is a translation product of the human UGT1A1 gene.
A protein that is a translation product of the human UGT1A3 gene.
A protein that is a translation product of the human UGT1A4 gene.
UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 1-6 is encoded by the human UGT1A6 gene. This protein is involved in the elimination of phenolic metabolites.
A protein that is a translation product of the mouse Ugt1a7c gene.
A protein that is a translation product of the human UGT1A8 gene.

A PPAR alpha and PPAR gamma target gene. The enzyme plays an important role in elimination and detoxification of drugs, xenobiotics, and metabolizing endogenous compounds, including catecholestrogens and fibrates.
A protein that is a translation product of the human UGT1A10 gene.
A protein that is a translation product of the human UGT2B4 gene
UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 2B7 is encoded by the human UGT2B7 gene. This protein plays a role in regulating the metabolism of estrogen metabolites.
A protein that is a translation product of the human UGT2B10 gene.
UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 2B15 is encoded by the human UGT2B15 gene. This protein is involved in the catabolism of xenobiotics and steroids.
A protein that contains a C-terminal UDPGT domain that in active form catalyzes the transfer of glucuronic acid to a wide variety of exogenous and endogenous lipophilic substrates.
A protein that is a translation product of the SLC10A1 gene
UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 2B17 is encoded by the human UGT2B17 gene. This protein plays a role in the metabolism of steroids and xenobiotics.
Background correction is a data transformation designed to remove irrelevant contributions from the measured signal, e.g. those due to instrument noise or sample preparation.

Image resize is a process to change the size of the image data by increasing or decreasing the number of pixels within the image. Mostly used for reducing in either the horizontal or vertical dimension.
Image sharpening is a process to enhance the definition of object edges in an image.
Image smoothing is a set of local pre-processing methods designed to suppress image noise.
Edge detection is the process to identify regions in a digital image where the image brightness changes sharply or the image has discontinuities.
Image thresholding is a procedure that eliminates shades of gray from regions of an image above or below particular gray levels, replacing them instead with solid white or black.
Any  method that simply measures the overall abundance (concentration, relative amount, etc) of a particular molecule (lipids, second messenger, nucleic acid, protein, etc.)

Second messengers relay and amplify signals from receptors to the cell interior as part of a signaling event. Examples include cAMP, cGMP, calcium, nitric oxide, diacylglycerol, etc. Levels of these second messengers are measured to reflect strength of the signaling.
Measuring lipid abundance could include mass spec-based methods and lipid droplet formation, a fluorescent intensity+image analysis assay to measure lipid stored in droplets within a cell,
Cell density, typically measured by absorbance (often indicated as A600 or OD600), is often used for bacterial or fungal cultures as an indication of cell number, viability or proliferation.
Beta-galactosidase activity measurement method
Any  method that simply measures the overall abundance (concentration, relative amount, etc) of a nucleic acid (DNA or RNA), typically via hybridization methods

Any  method that simply measures the overall abundance (concentration, relative amount, etc) of a small molecule, such as LC-MS/MS or LC-UV. Typically used in both in vitro and in vivo ADME assays to monitor compound.
Any method that measures the size and shape of whole cells. Typically detected by microscopy or flow cytometry
Any method that measures the size and shape of structures or organelles within cells, such as nuclei, mitochindria, Golgi, ER or vesicles. Typically detected by microscopy or flow cytometry
Any study performed in a whole, living organism (usually an animal such as a mouse or rat).

Any study performed in a whole, living organism (usually an animal such as a mouse or rat), to test the effects of a treatment on a specific disease modeled in this animal. Study design and measured endpoints vary tremendously and depend on the particular aspects of the targeted disease. Ideally, the endpoints measured will correlate with how efficacy would be measured in humans.
Any study performed in a whole, living organism (usually an animal such as a mouse or rat) to investigate the pharmacokinetics (PK), pharmacodynamics (PD) or toxicity of a perturbagen or treatment.

Changes in protein thermal stability can be induced by ligand binding, and this thermodynamic stabilization can be measured by a variety of methods, often reported as a delta Tm (or change in the melting temperature of the protein).
A method that uses chemilumiscence to quantify the labeled entity. For this, an enzyme converts a substrate to a  product that emits photons of light

A method that is used to identify the precise order/sequence of the nucleotides in a dna molecule by using the shotgun method in which DNA is fragmented and then the individual frgaments are sequenced
